verb.description: Rid (someone) of an unwanted feeling, memory, or condition, typically giving a sense of cathartic release.
examples: Bob had helped purge Martha of the terrible guilt that had haunted her

noun.description: An abrupt or violent removal of a group of people from an organization or place.
examples: a purge of the ruling class is absolutely necessary
a victim of the cultural purges

origin: Middle English (in the legal sense clear oneself of a charge): from Old French purgier, from Latin purgare purify, from purus pure.
